Harmonize the legal arsenal and put in place a manual on the monitoring, evaluation and management of chemicals and chemical-related events.
Inventory and strengthen the capacity of toxicological analysis laboratories.
Set up a National Poison Control and Toxicovigilance Center.
Establish a coordination mechanism among all stakeholders in chemical safety, industry, transportation, safe product disposal and health.
Develop an intersectoral action plan that includes monitoring, alerting and responding to a chemical event.

Organize seminars to sensitize senior medical personnel to Radiation Protection and Radiological Medical Emergencies, and then create a Radiation Protection Module as part of the Advanced Medical University curriculum.
Finalize Mali's national radiological emergency plan, including the responsibilities assigned to each actor in this plan.
Use already existing means for the evaluation of internal contamination. To this end, establish a framework agreement between the hospitals and AMARAP.
Establish a hospital triage protocol for radiological injuries based on cross-checking of symptomatic observations and haematological examinations using the METREPOL approach.
Set up a hotline system of available radiological expertise available 24/7.

Establish an intersectoral committee integrating the legal services of the ministerial departments concerned with the implementation of the IHR (2005) to carry out a systematic analysis of the national legislation / regulations in relation to the implementation of the IHR (2005) in order to identify the deficiencies to be corrected.
Adapt if necessary by regulatory and / or legislative means to facilitate the implementation of the IHR (2005) for the results of the review.
Advocate with the State and technical and financial partners to technically and financially support the implementation of the IHR (2005).
Advocate with the government for a sustainable source of IHR funding (2005).

Formalize by regulation the appointment of the National Focal Point RSI taking into account for its composition of the different domains of the RSI (2005) (health, agriculture, breeding, trade industry, security and transport).
Train members of the National RSI Focal Point and other authorities involved in the implementation of the IHR (2005) in the performance of their duties.
Develop standard operating procedures with the participation of all relevant sectors to facilitate the coordination, communication and promotion of the IHR (2005).
Set up a platform for exchange and communication between members of the National RSI Focal Point.
Finalize, validate and disseminate the national plan for the detection and reporting of antimicrobial resistant pathogens by integrating the private sector.

Develop, validate and disseminate a national plan for nosocomial infection control programs. Establish a multidisciplinary and multisectoral technical group to implement this plan using the One Health approach.
Strengthen the laboratories' technical platforms for the detection of antimicrobial resistance.
Develop and implement national guidelines for monitoring emerging zoonoses using the One Health approach.
Develop and disseminate procedures for collaboration and information-sharing between surveillance systems in animal, human and environmental health, including outside crisis episodes.
Develop, validate and implement the various plans to fight against zoonoses (contingency, surveillance, eradication, management).
Integrate training in field epidemiology and the fight against zoonoses into training programs for human, animal and environmental health personnel.

Conduct the inventory of domestic animals on the one hand to provide the OIE with the data required to evaluate the use of antibiotics, on the other hand to allow the appropriate allocation of human resources.
Develop and disseminate Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for collaboration and information sharing among stakeholders involved in food safety pending establishment of a Food Safety Agency.
Develop a multisectoral plan to detect and respond to events related to food safety.
Finalize the process of adoption of the draft framework law on food safety.
Strengthen the analytical capacity of national food quality control laboratories.
Finalize and adopt the national law on safety and biosecurity.

Develop and disseminate tools for documentation, notification, investigation and response to biological accidents / incidents and encourage structures that handle or store biological agents to develop, implement and evaluate their operational plans for safety and security biological safety.
Establish mechanisms for evaluating biological safety and security and procedures for officially classifying laboratories based on their biological containment capabilities.
Develop and implement a national training program on biological safety and security for laboratory personnel and all those handling biological agents.
Update the waste management plan by involving several sectors concerned.
Finalize, validate and implement at least 80% of the data quality improvement plan within three years.

Extend the supply of vaccines to zoonoses by systematically involving animal health authorities in the development of various vaccination plans (Comprehensive Multi-Year Plan, EPI Annual Work Plan, Maintenance Plan, Logistics Plan, etc.).

Continue to build the capacity of the various actors (logistics skills, vaccine management, use of related tools) to prevent vaccine breaks and losses, and increase routine immunization coverage for measles in children of 0 at 12 months from 80% to 90% within three years.

Establish an advocacy strategy with the Government and technical and financial partners to equip the districts with solar energy cold chain equipment, ensure maintenance (preventive and curative), and thus achieve a vaccine availability of at least 90% at the operational level, within three years.
Establish the intersectoral network of human, animal and environmental health laboratories, including food safety.

Strengthen the laboratory's technical platform in terms of human resources, laboratory equipment and consumables, regular supply of reagents and diagnostic kits, but also in terms of training in equipment maintenance.
Set up a harmonized and secure transport / sample transfer system at all levels with standardized operating procedures.
Establish a national quality assurance and external quality assurance program for all laboratories in different sectors.
Adopt and disseminate the various documents of the national strategic plan for laboratory development.
Develop and implement standard operating procedures for integration of surveillance activities in accordance with the provisions of the SIMR while taking into account the One Health approach.
Strengthen the capacities of the health staff in IDSR through training, refresher courses and formative supervision, after situational needs analysis.
Adapt and implement at all levels of the health pyramid, the technical guidelines of the WHO AFRO community-based surveillance.
Develop and implement a data quality improvement plan and a monitoring and evaluation plan for the RNIS.
Develop a platform for data sharing and surveillance information between the human, animal and environmental health sectors as part of the "One Health" approach.

Develop and disseminate to all stakeholders of the National RSI Focal Point, standard operating procedures for the approval and notification to WHO, OIE or FAO of events likely to constitute an Emergency of Public Health of International Scope (USSPI) as part of the One Health approach.
Strengthen the capacity of the National RSI Focal Point through training, financial and logistical support to improve its performance, including notification to WHO within 24 hours
Organize simulation exercises to test the collaboration and coordination of the actors involved in the notification of events that could constitute a USPPI.
Develop and implement a national human resources development plan, taking into account the evaluation of existing plans and the One Health approach, and incorporating a capitalization strategy.
Mapping human resources according to the "One Health" approach and putting in place a mechanism for territorial deployment of staff.
Strengthen the training of surveillance actors at different levels (central, intermediate and peripheral) in field epidemiology FETP type.
Continue and expand the retention project for specialized health personnel involved in the implementation of the IHR (2005) in areas of difficult access.
Develop a multi-sector national multi-risk plan for public health emergency preparedness and response taking into account existing plans and mapping already completed.
Finalize comprehensive mapping of all national resources to develop a management and distribution plan for the resources needed to implement the IHR (2005).
Continue the mapping risk exercises to test prepared preparedness plans.
Advocate for strengthening the budget line allocated to the preparation and management of public health emergencies.

Finalize and disseminate the regulatory texts governing the creation, missions, operation and activation of the COUSP by specifying the methods of communication with the local and regional levels as well as the national partners (information and feedback).
Make the COUSP operational 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, including the allocation of significant resources in terms of personnel, logistics and financing.
Validate and implement operational plans and procedures for emergency response.

Develop and share a strategic plan of the COUSP taking into account existing plans and the documents necessary for its operation: incident management, command, planning, financing, case management applied for IHR hazards (2005).

tech_area: Linking Public Health and Security Authorities
priority: Develop and implement standard operating procedures for coordinating joint action and information sharing between public health and security authorities in emergency situations.

tech_area: Linking Public Health and Security Authorities
priority: Strengthen the capacities of public health and security staff, including the establishment of a joint training program and simulation exercises.

Finalize, validate, simulate, disseminate and implement the national medical supply chain plan, integrating the procedures for sending and receiving medical devices, and deploying personnel for emergency response.
Establish an information system for effective management of medical facilities throughout the supply chain.
Develop an international partnership to support the sending and receiving of medical facilities, and the deployment of emergency response personnel on the basis of objective criteria.
Develop a plan for sending and receiving health personnel during a public health emergency.
Develop and implement a national risk communication plan taking into account existing sectoral communication plans.
Formally establish a multisectoral framework for consultation and harmonization for communication in emergencies.
Develop and disseminate standard operating procedures for communication in emergency situations.
Develop, disseminate and implement a national plan for collecting and managing rumors.
Develop and implement a capacity building plan for all stakeholders on risk communication, taking into account the "one health" spirit.
Finalize, validate, disseminate to all stakeholders the Strategic Plan for Cross-Border Surveillance in Cameroon integrated with other public health action plans.
Organize regular and intersectoral simulation exercises.

Revise and formally designate entry points in relation to the IHR (2005) and make available to all designated ports of entry the appropriate medical services, including personnel, equipment, adequate premises and diagnostic facilities for examination and taking fast charge of sick travelers.
Test and update data collection tools (including District Health Information Software DHIS2) at ports of entry.
Develop standard operating procedures for the inspection of means of transport and for the identification and transfer of patients to specialized medical facilities.

Develop and implement guidelines for the monitoring, evaluation and management of chemical-related events, intoxications or post-inventory poisoning of major sources of chemical hazards (industries, refineries, warehouses), and set priorities to develop contingency plans
Develop a chemical event management contingency plan that is part of the national plan for managing public health events.
Establish laboratories to control the diagnosis, analysis and quality of chemicals with the necessary human and material resources.
Strengthen multisectoral coordination mechanisms for response to chemical events and chemical safety.
Create multisectoral coordination mechanisms to implement waste regulations in health facilities, laboratories, pharmacies and others.
Finalize, validate, implement the national multisectoral radiological emergency plan.
Finalize and officially designate hospitals for case management by strengthening their skills (human and material resources).
Develop and implement a simulation exercise plan.
Set up an inter-sectoral Committee of Legal Technical Advisors (CTJ) which will review the existing national texts before it can identify the texts that need to be adapted to the IHR.

Strengthen the state's ability to adapt and align with legislation, policies and administrative arrangements at the national level to enable the implementation of the IHR (2005), based on the WHO's guide on strengthening of the RSI legislation.
Advocate with the state and technical and financial partners for strengthening and enforcing legislation.
Naming by regulatory means a PFNRSI.
Develop standard operating procedures for coordination between NTFP and different sectors.
Guarantee sustainable funding for the activities of PFNRSI.
Establish an operational exchange platform to institutionalize the One Health concept at the different levels of the health system.
Consider animal health and the environment in the National Antimicrobial Resistant Pathogen Surveillance Plan and Infection Prevention and Control.
Develop an antimicrobial management plan.
Strengthen the capacity of national reference laboratories (human health, animal health) for the detection of antimicrobial resistance.
Monitor the national plan for the fight against priority Zoonoses (DEP) and regularly update the contingency plans and control plans developed.
Develop a public-private partnership to meet the needs of veterinary cadres in the health system.
Develop and implement a diploma continuing education plan in the field of field epidemiology.
Establish a mechanism for exchange between veterinary health services and human health services for better management of zoonoses.

Design by ministerial decree a national reference laboratory and develop standard operating procedures (SOPs) and standard operating procedures (SOPs) to be applied to any suspect case of food poisoning.
Under the auspices of the DNSP, identify multidisciplinary local teams (peripheral, intermediate and central) trained in the investigation of food-related disease outbreaks.
Develop and implement a 10-year plan for food safety control management (laboratory, human and animal health structure, HS and SA focal points, sociologists and traditional communicators).

Develop and implement a national plan for biological safety and security involving cross-sectoral synergy (human, animal, environmental) with the support and endorsement of the government as a whole (DNSP).

Develop, validate and apply standard operating procedures for each class of pathogens (with an up-to-date registry and inventory) within structures that store or handle hazardous pathogens and toxins (DNSP).
Provide regular quality control (DPMED, ANV-SSP and DNSP).
Develop advocacy with the authorities to gradually increase the financial contribution of the State in the budget of the national immunization plan in order to preserve and sustain the gains.
Improve the synergy of action between the health sector and the animal sector.
Expand the delivery of vaccines to zoonoses (DNSP).
Integrate the animal sector into the next CMAP 2019-2023 plan.
Strengthen the operational capacity of laboratories in particular by equipping them with qualified and stable staff.
Create a national operational quality control committee.
Establish a national quality assurance program for central laboratories.
Exchange initially to seek the mutualization of material and human resources with human and animal health on advanced technologies.
Put in place a structured system for monitoring events that could threaten public health.
Operate the interoperable and interconnected real-time electronic notification system.
Ensure the financing of the internet connection for a prompt and complete transmission of surveillance data.
Produce and disseminate systematically newsletters and monitoring reports.
Strengthen the mechanism of formal exchanges between animal health and human health.
Establish a formal mechanism for the National IHR Focal Point and the WHO and OIE Focal Point to Exchange Information (RPFN).

Overall, the reporting capacity remains to be strengthened by the definition of the terms of reference of its members and the establishment of a reporting mechanism and procedures for WHO, OIE and FAO.
Develop standard operating procedures for approval and notification for any public health emergency of potential international concern to WHO, OIE, and FAO (DNSP, DE).
Strengthen human resources by providing for the recruitment of specialists as part of the implementation of the IHR at the next recruitment.
Develop integrated motivation strategies for all staff involved in the IHR (2005).
Continue training of field epidemiologists by setting up the intermediate level of the FETP program.
Develop a multi-sector national public health emergency preparedness and response plan to ensure the core capacity required under the IHR
Advocate to strengthen the budget line for the preparation and management of health emergencies.
Develop a plan for the management and distribution of national resources (human, material and financial resources) on the basis of the available evaluation
Support the DNSP by providing financial resources to operationalize the COUS.
Harmonize between PFNRSI and COUS members.
Identify and train the staff required for the operation of the COUS.
Develop the norms, procedures and legal texts to govern the operation of the COUS.

priority: Put in place regulatory and legal provisions for the management of cases of emergency health or the quarantine of these cases at the country level.

Develop an integrated plan for sending and receiving medical facilities and personnel compatible with the system in place for emergency management (COUS, ORSEC plan, contingency plan) taking into account the regulatory, logistical, security and financial dimensions .
Support the implementation of the plan developed within the different sectors.
Test the implementation of the plan through a practical exercise.
Develop and implement an Integrated Risk Communication Plan (COUS).
Create and strengthen the capacity of a risk communication unit at all levels of the health system.
Formalize mechanisms and procedures for listening and managing rumors.
Finalize, test and validate standard operating procedures for entry points.
Build and equip health posts at the 5 priority entry points (airport and port of Cotonou and the 3 land entry points) and ensure their operation.
Provide training / retraining of the different actors at entry points on the implementation of the IHR.
Strengthen intersectoral coordination for the implementation of IHR at entry points.
Develop a national intervention plan for emergencies at ports of entry and develop it into specific plans for each of the designated points of entry.
Establish and institutionalize an inter-ministerial commission bringing together all stakeholders in the field of risk management and chemical event with a budgeted action plan.
Develop an action plan for Health and Environment as part of the implementation of the Libreville Declaration.
Set up a system for monitoring risks and events of chemical origin (poison control center, toxicovigilance, etc.).
Update the chemical profile of Benin by including the nomenclature of chemicals.
Support advocacy to accelerate the vote on the nuclear law (MS, WHO, IAEA).
Appoint an authority for radionuclear risk and event management and establish coordination mechanisms with the relevant sectors.
Develop and implement a national action plan and functional mechanisms for the detection and response to radiological and nuclear emergencies.
Set up a monitoring system for radionuclear events.
